You are right that it can be frustrating when elected officials prioritize their donors over their constituents. Here are some potential ways to increase accountability of elected officials and reduce the influence of big money in politics:

1. Campaign finance reform: One of the most direct ways to reduce the influence of big money is by introducing comprehensive campaign finance reform measures. These might involve public financing of campaigns, strict limits on donations from donors, and increased disclosure requirements for campaign spending.

2. Lobbying transparency: Another strategy is to increase transparency around lobbying activities, such as by requiring registration of lobbyists and reporting of lobbying activities to the public. This can help make sure that elected officials are being influenced by a wide range of voices rather than just a select group of donors.

3. Citizen action: Citizen action is another way to put pressure on elected officials and make sure they are accountable to their constituents. This can involve organizing and mobilizing around specific issues or candidates, contacting elected officials to express concerns, and participating in public demonstrations and events.

4. Public awareness: Raising awareness about the problem of big money in politics among the general public is also important. This involves educating citizens about the issue and its implications for democracy, and encouraging people to actively engage in the political process.

These are just a few potential strategies, and there may be others that work well in different contexts. Ultimately, reducing the influence of big money in politics will require a sustained effort from all stakeholders – citizens, elected officials, political parties and advocacy organizations - to work together.
